awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: SI2-CHE:  Development and Deployment of Chemical Software for Advanced Potential Energy Surfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
An international team consisting of Teresa Head-Gordon and Martin Head-Gordon (University of California, Berkeley), Paul Nerenberg (Claremont McKenna College), David Case (Rutgers University), Jay Ponder (Washington University), Mark Tuckerman (New York University) with their UK collaborators: Lorna Smith and Neil Chue Hong (University of Edinburgh), Chris-Kriton Skylaris and Jonathan W. Essex (University of Southampton), Ilian Todorov (Daresbury Laboratory), Mario Antonioletti (EPCC) are are supported through the SI2-CHE program to develop and deploy robust and sustainable software for advanced potential energy surfaces.  The greater accuracy introduced by improvements in the new generation of potential energy surfaces opens up several challenges in their manifestation as algorithms and software on current or emergent hardware platforms that in turn limits their wide adoption by the computational chemistry community. The research team is overcoming these obstacles via multiple but integrated directions: (1) to optimally implement advanced potential energy surfaces across multi-core and GPU enabled systems, (2) to develop a hierarchy of advanced polarizable models that alter the tradeoff between accuracy and computational speed,(3) to create new multiple time stepping methods; (4) to write a Quantum Mechanics/Molecular Mechanics (QM/MM ) application programing interface (API) that fully supports mutual polarization, (5) to adopt software best practices to ensure growth of a self-sustaining community and (6) to provide exemplar calculations with the new software in the several emerging application areas.

Molecular simulation and quantum chemistry software is an integral part of chemistry and chemical biology, and has been broadly adopted by academic researchers and industry scientists. Next generation scientific breakthroughs that utilize chemical software will be enabled by the deployment of state of the art theoretical models and algorithms that are translated into a sustainable software framework rapidly implemented on emergent high performance computing platforms. Potential energy surfaces describe the interactions between atoms. Advanced and highly accurate potential energy surfaces encounter software-related obstacles that inhibit their application to grand challenge chemistry problems. This UK and US consortium, representing a broad cross section of the computational chemistry software community, is working to directly tackle these obstacles.   This US and UK collaboration between universities and High Performance Computing centers works to endure that chemical software investments made in advanced potential energy surface models has a long term payoff in community sustainability and the training of the next generation of scientists. Outreach and training workshops are organized around the emergence of the advanced potential energy software including an introductory molecular simulation software boot camp for undergraduate students.

The US based investigators are supported by the CHE and ACI divisions within NSF; the UK based investigators are supported by the EPSRC.

por.por_cntn:
This project advanced computational models and software infrastructure for molecular modeling. Robust models for atomic-level empirical potential energy functions ("force fields") for computer simulation of bulk systems and biomolecules were developed. The AMOEBA (Atomic Multipole Optimized Energetics for Biomolecular Applications) force field and TINKER modeling software package were the specific tools utilized across much of the project. AMOEBA is a next-generation model of the interactions within and between molecules in terms of straightforward physical effects. The goal of the model is to provide "chemical accuracy" of approximately 1 kcal/mol in the modeling and prediction of thermodynamic properties, such as the binding affinity of a drug for its protein target. The project largely achieved this goal by incorporating additional needed physics into the AMOEBA formalism. For example, "charge penetration" is now treated within AMOEBA in order to describe the overlap of real molecular electron clouds under the point-property description used in the force field. Inclusion of this simple effect via an appropriately calibrated damping function roughly halves the error in AMOEBA calculations.

Another avenue explored during the project was use of advanced potential energy models, such as AMOEBA, in combination with quantum mechanical methods, so-called quantum mechanics/molecular mechanics (QM/MM) computations. As a prototype QM/MM methodology, we paired the AMOEBA force field with ONETEP, an efficient linear-scaling density functional theory-based QM software package. QM/MM approaches show promise as a multi-scale molecular modeling technique, where the QM model can be used locally to treat making and breaking of chemical bonds and AMOEBA is used to provide a polarizable background environment.

Finally, a major component of the project was to increase the efficiency and parallelization of AMOEBA calculations through the TINKER software. TINKER is a large software system consisting of about 60 separate computer programs that interoperate to perform a range of molecular modeling tasks. Advances in methods for calculation of AMOEBA induced dipole moments were made via application of a new method for propagation of the dipoles during a molecular dynamics simulation (ie, extended Lagrangian methods). In addition the most computationally intensive portions of the TINKER software were rewritten and refactored to increase there ability to run in parallel on multi-core computer systems. By the end o the project, we produced a parallel TINKER code with a roughly six-fold or greater increase in throughput on widely available 8- to 16-core computer workstations.

Under the funding provided to this project, we released a significantly new version of our software, TINKER 8, in February of 2017. This new version of TINKER represents a nearly optimal OpenMP implementation of the polarizable multipole electrostatics, and will form the basis of our ongoing work on a message-passing implementation of TINKER for use on large-scale supercomputer systems, as well as a derived code base targeting commodity grpahical processing unit (GPU) systems.
